awd_titl_txt: On the Mechanics of Ripplocations: A New Defect in Layered Solids
awd_abstract_narration:
Recent discoveries in layered materials have opened new dimensions for tailoring better materials. Layered materials are ubiquitous in our surroundings; they encompass graphite, mica, and two-dimensional solids (with an atomic-scale thickness), among many others. It has long been understood that for solids to deform, microscopic defects must be present. Up to quite recently these defects were presumed to be line defects called dislocations, a well-known and studied material defect. In 2016, however, research suggested that conventional wisdom was incorrect, or incomplete, regarding the deformation of layered materials. A potentially new micro-mechanism called a ripplocation, best described as an atomic scale ripple, was suggested as the governing mechanism. At the macroscale, a ripplocation would be a carpet ripple. Currently, little is known about these defects, their mechanics or behavior, and how to leverage them to create improved materials. This research investigates the mechanics of ripplocation through an integrated suite of modeling and experimentation at two length scales. The overall goal integrates fields of mechanics, materials science, and scientific computing to build a platform to engineer more advanced materials as well as provide fundamental knowledgebase to the technology sectors where layers materials are relevant, such as geo-technology and microelectronics. Also, as part of the research, outreach to high school students will be made through summer programs, undergraduate and graduate students from underrepresented groups will be hired to perform research, and interactive learning modules will be added to the curriculum to educate the next generation of diverse scientists and engineers.

Fundamental differences between ripplocation and dislocation behavior exist and motivate the current project. According to dislocation theory, when the planes of layered solid materials are loaded and unloaded edge-on they will either reversibly deform, and return to their original form without dissipating any energy if it's an elastic material or they will remain permanently indented. Ripplocation behavior explains the third observed option, which is the material returning to its original form, while dissipating considerable amounts of energy. The goal of this work is to understand ripplocation mechanics at multiple levels, from the atomic, through molecular modeling and theory, to the macroscopic where layered solids will be indented. Results from molecular modeling to capture the fundamental physics of ripplocations will be leveraged to create a new ripplocation dynamics model. Indentation predictions, including both strength and microstructural deformation, from the model will be directly compared to and verified with results from atomistic modeling at the nanoscale and experimental indentation studies at the microscale. The goal is to show that ripplocation mechanics are scale invariant and provide a mechanics-based predictive framework that can be extended to a myriad of other layered materials to enable improved design strategies.

por.por_cntn:
A new fundamental understanding into the mechanical behavior of layered materials, through integrated experimental and computational research, occurred by studying a newly proposed defect, termed a ripplocation. Essentially a buckling mechanism, ripplocations are now known to operate from the nanoscale to macroscale in layered materials. Our collaborative effort demonstrated, for the first time, how this mechanism nucleates at the atomic-scale, and may evolve to kinking commonly observed in layered systems. Scientific questions about kinking, and its mechanistic origins, have been long-standing issues in the materials community. Accordingly, as this project helped to uncover some of those origins of the mechanical deformation and layered materials and provide answers about a potentially new defect, our research results have significant intellectual merit.

In this project we used graphite and MAX phase ceramics as model materials to study buckling and ripplocations. Like for graphite, and presumably all layered crystalline materials, the driving force for the entire process is strain redistribution from energetically more expensive in-plane bonds to cheaper out-of-plane bonds. A process that occurs in many layered systems. As ripplocations combine to form stacked structures, the elastic strains can be quite high indeed. In our work, we focused on the MAX phases and graphite, however, given the close resemblance of kink boundaries observed herein to those in other layered crystalline solids - such as mica, and other layered silicates, ice, etc. - it is reasonable to assume it has universal validity. 

In graphite, the fundamental mechanics of ripplocations differs from that observed in MAX phases. Our work points to an altered behavior under mechanical deformation and evolution of strain accommodation. These results indicate that a new direction in the analysis of deformation in layered solids is now needed. Analyzing the kinematic signatures of deformed materials, we have leveraged calculating both the stored energy and disregistry between graphite layers ? demonstrating the unique structure of various defects using newly developed computational tools. Further, we have further probed the influence of interlayer bonding strength, on ripplocation/buckling behavior in graphite. Upon increasing the strength, the ripplocation nucleation event is significantly altered, and appears to be more representative of other defect structures commonly observed in stiffer layered materials, as often seen in MAX phases. Finally, newly developed atomistic approaches now provide a quantitative distinction between traditionally understood deformation models and those from ripplocation-based theories. 

The results of this project could impact the field of materials science and materials mechanics by illuminating many outstanding questions regarding deformation and energy dissipation within layered materials. As it has long been assumed that the operative mechanism to accommodate strain and drive deformation in all layered materials was the basal dislocation. We have successfully shown that to be incomplete, and ripplocation mechanics and buckling must also be accounted for to accurately predict deformation within layered materials and improve next generation materials design. This new insight implies that a large body of work will need to be re-examined and updated, some of which we are still pursuing. 

Outcomes from this project reach past the direct intellectual merit achieved. Detailed predictions of mechanical behavior could potentially play a role in the synthesis of novel devices and new technology. Furthermore, a newly developed ripplocation mechanics model could be quite beneficial to a range of disciplines where layered materials or structures that undergo deformation through ripplocation behavior. This includes materials including layered or ordered metals, mechanical engineering, civil engineering, geophysics, and geology. Furthermore, the advancement in knowledge and techniques could also influence scientific computing and numerical methods. A broader impact of this project would be its potential influence on geology and geophysics disciplines, if the mechanistic origins of buckling is further progressed, it can help recognize the influence of confinement, inter- vs. intra-lamellar mechanics, and energy dissipation in numerous layered crystalline solids.
